metadata.case_name: Appellant Company v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: Appellant is a limited company incorporated under the Travancore Companies Regulation carrying on business in Kerala of manufacturing sugar, running a distillery and a tincture factory.

Appellant-company floated to take over business assets of Travancore Sugars Ltd. (being wound up, State Government held largest shares), Government Distillery at Nagercoil and Government Tincture Factory at Trivandrum.
Agreement dated June 18, 1937 between Government of Travancore and Sir William Wright on behalf of Parry Co. Ltd., promoters of appellant-company, for sale of assets of three concerns to appellant.
Clause 3: Cash consideration for Travancore Sugars Ltd. assets = Rs. 3.25 lakhs.
Clause 4(a): Cash consideration for Government Distillery by joint valuation by engineers.
Clause 5(a): Cash consideration for Government Tincture Factory = book value.
Clauses 4(b) and 4(c): Government to recognise transfer of licence to appellant and secure continuance for continuous period of five years after existing licence.
Clause 5(b): Government agreed to purchase pharmaceutical products from appellant's Tincture Factory for medical requirements.
Clause 6: Books of account open to inspection by Government officers.
Clause 10: Government entitled to nominate a director on appellant's Board without voting power or interference in normal management.
Clause 7 (original): Government entitled to 20% of net profits per year, max Rs. 40,000, after deductions for expenditure, depreciation per IT law, and secretaries-treasurers remuneration.
Agreement dated January 28, 1947 substituted Clause 7: Government entitled to 10% of net profits as assessed to Income-tax in Travancore.
For assessment year 1958-59 (previous year May 1, 1956 to April 30, 1957), amount payable to Government under Clause 7 = Rs. 42,480/-
Appellate Assistant Commissioner disallowed deduction of Rs. 42,480/- as mere sharing of profits after existence, relied on Pondicherry Railway Co. v. CIT.
Appellant appealed to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, which allowed deduction holding it within British Sugar Manufacturers Ltd. v. Harris, as expenditure to earn profits, not out of earned profits.
At instance of respondent, Tribunal referred question to Kerala High Court: Whether payment of Rs. 42,480/- allowable under s.10 of Income-tax Act?
Kerala High Court by judgment dated August 20, 1963 held payment constituted capital expenditure, not allowable under s.10(2)(xv), did not address division of profits.
Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave from Kerala High Court judgment.
Preamble to 1947 agreement recites original 1937 agreement consideration included cash plus 20% net profits entitlement.

legal_issues.text: Whether the payment of Rs. 42,480/- to Travancore Government under agreements dated 18-6-1937 and 28-1-1947 was allowable under s.10 of the Income-tax Act?
Whether the payment constituted capital expenditure or revenue expenditure allowable under s.10(2)(xv)?
Whether the payment tantamount to diversion of profits by paramount title?
Whether the transaction a joint venture with profit sharing?

petitioner_arguments.text: Payment of Rs. 42,480/- not capital expenditure but revenue nature allowable under s.10(2)(xv); annual payments under cl.7 not part of purchase price; separate cash considerations in cls.3,4(a),5(a); payments in consideration of govt obligations in cls.4(b),(c),5(b).
Payment tantamount to diversion of profits by paramount title.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Raja Bejoy Singh Dudhuria v. CIT; Poona Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. CIT

petitioner_arguments.text: Payment wholly and exclusively laid out for purpose of business.

respondent_arguments.text: Payment part of purchase price per preamble to 1947 agreement.
Payment out of profits on condition of profits earned, not to earn profits.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Pondicherry Railway Co. Ltd. v. CIT

respondent_arguments.text: Transaction a joint venture with agreement to share profits.

court_reasoning.text: Difficult to distinguish capital vs revenue; court looks at documents and surrounding circumstances from commercial view; no single test.
court_reasoning.key_observation: True nature from covenants and circumstances.

court_reasoning.text: Consideration for sale: (1) cash per cls.3,4(a),5(a); (2) 20% net profits max Rs.40,000 p.a.; payment indefinite period, related to annual profits from trading not capital value, not tied to fixed sum.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No specific capital sum for instalments; excludes connection to capital.

court_reasoning.text: Instalments of fixed capital price remain capital; here no fixed sum or relation to price.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Payment revenue expenditure; overrule Kerala HC.

court_reasoning.text: Cannot finally determine appeal as HC did not deal with other questions: diversion by paramount title, joint venture, s.10(2)(xv) requirements.

holdings.text: Payment of annual sum of Rs.42,480/- is not capital expenditure but revenue expenditure.

precedents_cited.relevance: Relied by AAC to disallow as sharing profits.

precedents_cited.case_name: British Sugar Manufacturers Ltd. v. Harris
precedents_cited.relevance: Tribunal held payment expenditure to earn profits.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. 36/49 Holdings Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Similar: commission on turnover indefinite period, not part of fixed price; revenue nature.

precedents_cited.case_name: CIT v. Kolhia Hirdagarh Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Payment indefinite, related to turnover not fixed price; revenue.

precedents_cited.case_name: Minister of National Revenue v. Catherine Spooner
precedents_cited.relevance: Special facts: share in oil, not profit; exceptional.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jones v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents_cited.relevance: Percentage on sales as royalty; income nature as dependent on business volume.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raja Bejoy Singh Dudhuria v. CIT
precedents_cited.relevance: Diversion by paramount title via court decree charging estate.

precedents_cited.case_name: Poona Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. CIT
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinction between commercial profits and statutory profits.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Allowability of payment as deduction; revenue expenditure wholly exclusively for business.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held the payment is revenue expenditure, overruling Kerala High Court on that point, but could not finally determine appeal as High Court did not address other issues like diversion of profits, joint venture, and s.10(2)(xv) requirements; matter remitted for consideration.
outcome.relief_granted: High Court judgment overruled on capital/revenue issue

key_quotes.text: It is often difficult, in any particular case, to decide and determine whether a particular expenditure is in the nature of capital expenditure or in the nature of revenue expenditure.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Introduces test for distinguishing capital vs revenue.

key_quotes.text: The payment of commission of twenty per cent on the net profits by the appellant in favour of the Government is for an indefinite period and has no limitation of time attached to it.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.key_observation: Key factor making it revenue: indefinite, profit-related, not fixed capital sum.

key_quotes.text: When a man does that he takes an income-it is in the nature of income.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quote from Jones v CIR applying to profit share as income.
